item.title: Waymo Applies for NYC Testing Permit, Sending Uber and Lyft Shares Lower
item.description: Alphabet Inc.’s Waymo has applied for a permit to test its robotaxis in New York City, underscoring its intent to operate in one of the largest ride-hailing markets in the US despite an absence of local regulations supporting commercially operated autonomous vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Lung, Davey Alba

media:content.media:description: A Waymo autonomous taxi in San Francisco, California, US, on Thursday Aug. 10, 2023. California regulators are poised to decide whether two rival robotaxi services can provide around-the-clock rides throughout San Francisco, despite escalating fears about recurring incidents that have caused the driverless vehicles to block traffic or imperil public safety, reported the AP.

item.title: Nvidia Joins $650 Million Funding for Gates-Backed Nuke Firm
item.description: TerraPower LLC, a nuclear startup founded by billionaire Bill Gates, raised $650 million to help continue development of an advanced reactor project under construction in Wyoming.
item.dc:creator: Will Wade

media:content.media:description: Nvidia offices in Taipei.

item.title: Trump Again Pushes TikTok Sale Deadline With 90-Day Reprieve
item.description: President Donald Trump plans to extend for a third time the deadline for Chinese company ByteDance Ltd. to divest the American operations of TikTok, allowing the social media app to keep running in the US while negotiations proceed.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai

media:content.media:description: TikTok Inc. offices in Culver City, California

item.title: Intel Brings in New Engineering Leaders to Help AI Comeback
item.description: Intel Corp. named new engineering leadership as part of a turnaround effort under Chief Executive Officer Lip-Bu Tan, tapping veterans of Cadence Design Systems Inc., Apple Inc. and Google.
item.dc:creator: Ian King

media:content.media:description: Intel Corp. headquarters in Santa Clara, California.

item.title: Justices Back Temporary Texas Nuclear Waste Storage Site
item.description: The US Supreme Court left intact a federal plan to store as much as 40,000 tons of highly radioactive waste at a temporary site in west Texas over the objections of local landowners and oil and gas operators.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr, Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC.

item.title: OpenAI Is Phasing Out Scale AI Work Following Startup’s Meta Deal
item.description: OpenAI is phasing out the work it does with data-labeling startup Scale AI, cutting ties with the company days after Meta Platforms Inc. invested billions of dollars in it and hired its founder.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Metz

media:content.media:description: Sam Altman, chief executive officer of OpenAI, speaks at Kakao Media Day in Seoul, South Korea, on Tuesday, Feb. 4, 2025. Kakao Corp. and OpenAI have agreed to integrate ChatGPT and other AI services more deeply into Korea’s largest social media platform, another significant customer win for Altman’s startup.

item.title: Amazon-Owned Zoox Opens Robotaxi Production Site in California
item.description: Amazon.com Inc.’s Zoox autonomous driving unit opened a robotaxi production facility in California in the latest move by a deep-pocketed tech company to expand the nascent industry.
item.dc:creator: Edward Ludlow

media:content.media:description: A Zoox autonomous robotaxi in San Francisco, California, US, on Wednesday, Dec. 4, 2024. Amazon owned Zoox Inc. has started testing its electric robotaxis in San Francisco's SoMa neighborhood.

item.title: Lab-Grown Meat Soon on Australia’s Menus After Approval
item.description: Australia has approved the sale of slaughter-free Japanese quail, becoming only the third country in the world to permit the sale of meat cultivated from animal cells.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka de Sousa

media:content.media:description: Forged cultured Japanese quail foie gras.

item.title: Chipmaker Wolfspeed Nears Bankruptcy Deal With Lenders Including Apollo
item.description: Struggling chipmaker Wolfspeed Inc. will be taken over by creditors including Apollo Global Management Inc. under a proposal that would put it into bankruptcy just long enough to slash billions in debt, according to people familiar with the plan.
item.dc:creator: Steven Church, Reshmi Basu

media:content.media:description: A Wolfspeed wafer

item.title: Broadcom’s 340% Rally Has Wall Street Debating If It's Magnificent Seven Material
item.description: For more than two years, conversations about the biggest, most important technology companies have revolved around the same seven stocks. Now, some on Wall Street are making the case that Broadcom Inc. should be part of that discussion.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Reinicke

media:content.media:description: Broadcom headquarters in San Jose, California.

item.title: Xreal’s One Pro Are a Stopgap Ahead of True AR Smart Glasses
item.description: Review: The company’s latest augmented-reality glasses excel as an external display for phones, PCs and gaming devices.
item.dc:creator: Chris Welch

media:content.media:description: Xreal’s One Pro AR smart glasses.

item.title: Tencent-Backed MiniMax Releasing AI Tools to Take On Manus
item.description: Chinese upstart MiniMax is slated to roll out a pair of AI products that autonomously perform tasks on behalf of users, upping its game in the realm of agentic AI against the likes of OpenAI and Manus.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Zheping Huang

item.title: Texas Instruments Touts Plans to Invest $60 Billion in the US
item.description: Texas Instruments Inc. touted plans to spend more than $60 billion on semiconductor plants in the US, making it the latest chipmaker to promote its domestic manufacturing ambitions as the Trump administration urges investments and threatens to upend the sector with tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Ian King, Mackenzie Hawkins

media:content.media:description: The Texas Instruments headquarters in Dallas, Texas, US, on Wednesday, Jan. 17, 2024. Texas Instruments Inc. released earnings figures on January 23.

item.title: Road to a $3.7 Trillion Stablecoin Market Is Full of Obstacles
item.description: The passage of stablecoin legislation in the US Senate marks a huge leap forward for the potential mainstreaming of cryptocurrencies that track the US dollar one-to-one.
item.dc:creator: Emily Nicolle, Anna Irrera, Emily Mason

media:content.media:description: Jeremy Allaire, chief executive officer of Circle Internet Group Inc., center, during the company’s initial public offering (IPO) on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange on June 5.

item.title: SoftBank-Backed Startup Misses Financial Goals, Slashes Staff
item.description: Just a couple years ago, Spotter Inc. was one of the most valuable startups in the booming business of YouTube celebrity. The company, which boasted a new way for social media stars to fund their operations, fronted millions of dollars to creators like MrBeast and Dude Perfect in exchange for a share of the revenue their videos generated.
item.dc:creator: Aisha Counts

media:content.media:description: Spotter CEO Aaron DeBevoise in Hollywood in 2022. Photographer: Kevin Winter/Getty Images

item.title: Iran-Israel Conflict Spreads to Hacks on Banks, Crypto
item.description: The conflict between Israel and Iran is spilling over into the digital world, inflaming a decades-long campaign of hacks and espionage between two nations renowned for their cyber prowess.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Howell O'Neill, Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: A poster bearing the image of Commander-in-Chief of the IRGC Hossein Salami, displayed in front of a Bank Sepah branch in Tehran on June 17, 2025.

item.title: Italy’s Brembo to Provide Brakes for US Bike Brand Specialized
item.description: Brembo NV will supply a braking system for US bicycle brand Specialized as part of a partnership the two companies are setting up, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Daniele Lepido

media:content.media:description: A Brembo logo on a motorcycle brake caliper.

item.title: Ad Industry Parties at Cannes in Face of Looming AI Upheaval
item.description: Welcome to Tech In Depth, our daily newsletter with reporting and analysis about the business of tech from Bloomberg’s journalists around the world. Today, Benoit Berthelot reports that the ad industry continues to party as usual at the annual Cannes Lions festival in France despite underlying anxiety about the coming effects of artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Berthelot

media:content.media:description: Atmosphere at Spotify Beach during Cannes Lions 2025 on June 17, 2025 in Cannes, France. (Photo by Antony Jones/Getty Images for Spotify)

item.title: Ex-SpaceX Staffers Raise Cash for Defense Manufacturing Startup
item.description: Senra Systems joins a growing list of startups aiming to accelerate American manufacturing of drones, rockets and more.
item.dc:creator: Lizette Chapman

media:content.media:description: The Anduril Ghost autonomous drone at Anduril's headquarters in Costa Mesa, California, US, on Thursday, Dec. 14, 2023. Anduril recently beat several legacy defense players in a contest for a major contract to develop an unmanned fighter jet for the US Air Force and is now valued at $8.5 billion.

item.title: UBS Confirms Data Stolen After Hack at External Supplier
item.description: UBS Group AG said that information about the company had been stolen in a cyber attack on one of its suppliers, following a report a Swiss newspaper that data on more than 130,000 employees had been subject to a hack.
item.dc:creator: Noele Illien

media:content.media:description: The UBS Group AG headquarters in Zurich. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg

item.title: Alibaba-Backed ‘AI Dragon’ MiniMax Is Said to Plan Hong Kong IPO
item.description: MiniMax is considering an initial public offering in Hong Kong, people familiar with the situation said, in what would be a landmark industry debut for a Chinese AI startup valued at about $3 billion.
item.dc:creator: Pei Li, Julia Fioretti, Luz Ding

media:content.media:description: The flags of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region , left, and Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd., right, in Hong Kong. Photographer: Yik Yeung-man/Bloomberg

item.title: SAP and IBM Unit Ensnared in $800 Million Quebec IT Fiasco
item.description: Software company SAP SE and an IBM Corp. subsidiary are embroiled in a C$1.1 billion ($810 million) technology boondoggle that triggered both a public inquiry and an anti-corruption investigation in Quebec.
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion

media:content.media:description: A logo at the SAP SE booth at the Hannover Messe 2025 trade fair in Hannover, Germany, on Monday, March 31, 2025. German inflation slowed more than anticipated in March, nearing the European Central Bank's 2% target as officials ponder whether to lower interest rates again at their next meeting or pause.

item.title: Netflix Adds Live TV Broadcasts, Sports From France’s TF1
item.description: Netflix Inc. will add live television channels and shows from French broadcaster TF1, expanding the streaming platform’s live offer for customers in the country.
item.dc:creator: Amy Thomson, Benoit Berthelot

media:content.media:description: The Netflix logo on a smartphone arranged in the Queens borough of New York, US, on Tuesday, March 26, 2024. Netflix Inc. is scheduled to release earnings figures on April 18.

item.title: EU Says AliExpress Failed to Stop Illegal Sales in DSA Probe
item.description: The European Union escalated a probe against Alibaba Group Holding Ltd.’s e-commerce service AliExpress, accusing it of failing to tackle the spread of illegal products on its platform.
item.dc:creator: Gian Volpicelli

media:content.media:description: The AliExpress app. Photographer: Kirill Kudryavtsev/Getty Images

item.title: Musk’s xAI Burns Through $1 Billion a Month as Costs Pile Up
item.description: Elon Musk’s artificial intelligence startup xAI is burning through $1 billion a month as the cost of building its advanced AI models races ahead of the limited revenues, according to people briefed on the company’s financials.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Arroyo, Jill R Shah

item.title: Star Capital Weighs IPO of Defense Tech Firm Vincorion
item.description: Star Capital is considering an initial public offering of German defense technology firm Vincorion, people familiar with the matter said, as rising investor interest lifts the value in European aerospace and defense assets.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Kirchfeld, Eyk Henning, Laura Alviz

media:content.media:description: Components for Puma infantry fighting vehicles at a Vincorion site.

item.title: KKR, GIC Are Among Final Bidders for MasOrange, Zegona Joint Venture
item.description: KKR & Co. and GIC Pte. are among the final bidders for a stake in a fiber-optic broadband network venture owned by MasOrange and Zegona Communications Plc, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Clara Hernanz Lizarraga, Vinicy Chan, Jillian Deutsch

media:content.media:description: Multi-colored fiber optic cables connected to a terminal.

item.title: How China Is Building a Powerful Army of Hackers
item.description: On today’s Big Take Asia podcast, how China’s domestic hacking competitions are helping boost the country’s cyber-espionage capabilities.
item.dc:creator: K Oanh Ha, Naomi Ng, Yang Yang

item.title: JD.com Billionaire Unveils Turnaround Plan After Five-Year Slump
item.description: JD.com Inc. founder Richard Liu vowed to speed an overseas foray and compete with Meituan in new arenas from food delivery to travel, describing his boldest attempt yet to revive an online retailer that’s languished since a 2020 government crackdown.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Zheping Huang, Claire Che

media:content.media:description: Richard Liu in Hong Kong in 2017. Photographer: Billy H.C. Kwok/Bloomberg

item.title: US-China Tech Fight Widens After Taiwan Blacklists Huawei
item.description: Taiwan joined a yearslong US campaign to curtail China’s technological ascent when it blacklisted the country’s AI and chipmaking champions, an unprecedented step that may signal a resurgent effort to isolate its powerful neighbor’s semiconductor sector.
item.dc:creator: Mackenzie Hawkins, Miaojung Lin, Yian Lee

media:content.media:description: A Huawei Technologies Co. store in Shanghai.
